data.title: Viewport appears to work only if is a child of Control Node
data.body:
It appears viewport only works if you add it as a child to a Control Node (thanks for hetdegon for figuring this out). So if I place viewport under any other node nothing happens just a black screen. Also the control needs to be set to width and height of the viewport. 

This deff seems like a hack and a bug and hardly appears intentional. 

edit: seems it may be intentional?? This was not documented anywhere.  

And even if you do that  to get the viewport working you will still get the issue described in #1840  Seems the viewport doesn't know how to zoom in and out with the rest of the editor and will just flood the entire editor screen instead.

data.title: StreamPlayer Loop Restart Time not a float but int in inspector
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 Pro, Godot 2.0.2 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The StreamPlayer class provides the float property "Loop Restart Time" and corresponding functions to get and set the value. The value specifies the time in seconds at which a looping stream is rewound to. The inspector erroneously displays it as an Integer property, and thus makes it very inexact / useless. A script which uses set_loop_restart_time(float) to properly set a float value for it is the only workaround.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a StreamPlayer. Try to set a float value for "Loop Restart Time" in the inspector. Since the field is an Integer there, it will be rounded to the next Integer, setting the loop time exactly is impossible without a script.

data.title: Proposal to add YAML support in addition to JSON
data.body:
Would be nice if we had the option to use YAML as an alternative to JSON. More versatility would be great. 

Also seems YAML can do things JSON cannot like : comments, extensible data types, strings without quotation marks and others.  And , according to Wikipedia, JSON can be parsed by YAML (ver 1.2) parsers making it a subset of YAML. So at second glance both of these are interchangeable and YAML does seem easier to write, read and more powerful than JSON. 

Obvs this is a low priority feature 
I will leave it up you to decide

Thanks. Keep up the good work ðŸ‘

data.title: Calling OS.shell_open() from inside a deferred_call() function messes up the call queue
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 7 Pro SP1
Intel Core i7 2.4GHz, 16GB RAM
Godot 2.0.2.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If you call `OS.shell_open()` from a function which was called by `deferred_call()` inside a `button_pressed()` signal handler, the execution of the deferred function itself is restarted al least one time, and often several times, especially if you keep moving the mouse after clicking the button.
I would expect the deferred function to be called only once for every button press.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a function named `deferred_open()`
2. Inside `deferred_open()` add `print("Deferred open")` followed by `OS.shell_open("anything")`
3. Add a button
4. Connect the `button_pressed()` signal to a function, let's say `_on_Button_pressed()`
5. Inside `_on_Button_pressed()`  add `call_deferred("deferred_open")`
6. Run the scene and click on the button: see that "Deferred open" is printed two times (or more)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I tried to upload a zipfile with an example project, but I keep getting the error "_Unfortunately, we donâ€™t support that file type. Try again with a PNG, GIF, JPG, DOCX, PPTX, XLSX, TXT, PDF, or ZIP._" (!?!), so here is an external link: http://www.olomatrix.org/godot/ShellOpenBug.zip

data.title: Trying to create API for reporting driver info for rasterizer
data.body: I am trying to make info about renderer output universally, but I don't know how to override class member in C++ (I am coming from Python). It still shows `Video driver: ???`. Any hints?

data.title: Can't close running game
data.body:
Ubuntu 64-bit 14.04

Can't close the running(frozen game -> error) game.
Closing the game is only with a kill command possible. This is also causing an issue that errors are not showing in godot anymore while this game is running.

1.Open a Scene, add some code that is causing an error `print(RawArray([0])==-1)`
2. Run this scene with "Play the edited scene(F6)" -> godot will show an error.
3. Leave the game running and choose Scene-> Quit to Project list -> BUG: Now godot is giong to the project list bug the game is not beeing closed and only can be closed with a kill commmand", dont't kill it!
4.Open the project again
5. do step 1 & step 2, Now godot is not showing the error but will only show the frozen game.

data.title: Adding a CollisionShape2D on an instanced Area2D in the editor does not work
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

Windows 10

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

In TestArea.tscn I have

```
TestArea (Area2D)
```

With script TestArea.gd:

```
extends Area2D

func _input_event(viewport, event, shape_idx):
    print(self.get_name())
```

If I add that to another scene main.tscn and add a CollisionShape2D to it:

```
Node2D
     -> TestArea (from TestArea.tscn)
               -> CollisionShape2D (added in main.tscn with rectangle shape) 
```

The CollisionShape2D doesn't seem to work and nothing is logged out.

I have attached an example project. To the left is an Area2D that was created in main.tscn. On the right is a TestArea loaded from TestArea.tscn
[collision_shape.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/222613/collision_shape.zip)

data.title: Dropping obsolete platforms
data.body:
We currently have an important number of platforms in `platform/`, but some of those have hardly been supported over the last two year, probably don't work and refer to somewhat obsolete technologies. Those would be:
- flash: @punto- hinted on IRC that this probably never really worked, it contains [nonfree files](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/platform/flash/Console.as), and well, Flash should die and I'd be for not even suggesting that we might be working on it. So: **drop**.
- nacl: I don't know if anyone even tried to build it since the opensourcing. NACL itself is still being somewhat developed, but should we spend time on it or just ditch it [Waiting for WebAssemblyâ„¢](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2016/03/a-webassembly-milestone/)? I'd propose to **drop**, but if others would like to keep it, why not.

Then we have:
- bb10: The personal favourite of @punto- AFAIK ;) I never tried to build it myself, but it seems BB10 is not 100% dead yet, so I guess we can keep it around until @punto- ditches his BB10 phone :p
- winrt: It might be somewhat broken nowadays because it hasn't been much worked on recently, but it should not be dropped, we need to add proper support for UWP.

WDYT? If there's no objection, I'd drop `platform/flash` and `platform/nacl`.

data.title: Unexpected quit when calling the 'find' method in 'RegEx' class.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu 15.10

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The program quits when trying to invoke the `find` method of an instance of a `RegEx` class.
You can check the regex demo. The demo quits unexpectedly.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a scene.
2. Add a `Node` as the root.
3. Create a script for the root node.
4. Incorporate the snippet below.
5. Run the current scene (press F6). _(expectation: program quits)_
6. Comment `regex.find("test")`.
7. Press F6. _(expectation: program ok)_

``` gdscript
func _ready():
    var pattern = "[a-z][a-z0-9]+"
    var regex = RegEx.new()
    regex.compile(pattern)
    if regex.is_valid():
        print("Regex valid")
    else:
        print("Regex not valid")
    regex.find("test")
```

data.title: Added getter method for the connection property in HTTPClient.
data.body: - Exposed a getter method for the private property named `connection` in HTTPClient class.

data.title: Extend the dock system
data.body:
**A feature request that docks can be placed at the bottom part of the editor too:**

The bottom part of the editor is treated like "three docks" (kind of..) It would be great if this space could be used for other docks too. Like the file browser to have access to some assets in the whole bottom part of the editor.
So it would be cool if the animation, Output and the Debug tab could be treated like any other dock.
(placed wherever the user wants them to be placed)
Since you often don't need these windows and I really like the concept of godot that only the things that are needed will be displayed, there possibly could be a button that lets the bottom area open and close. Or clicking the curent tab could minimized the bottom area. (and of course the bottom area should be opened automatically when an animationPlayer node is selected or the game is started...)

It also would be really useful to be able to place two docks at the bottom area. So you can have two docks at the same time. For example the debugger and the output window.

data.title: Pressing "Play button" in SampleLibrary crashes the engine
data.body:
Sorry if this is rushed, I'm mid way into Ludum Dare 35!

**Operating system or device:**
Linux Mint 17.3 x64
Using the Godot 2.0.2 official release for x11

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When I [press the "Play button" on this screen](http://i.imgur.com/rrqouOD.png) the engine just crashes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Make a SamplePlayer node
In the inspector, make a new SampleLibrary
Go into SampleLibrary (> arrow)
Open any .smp or .wav file
Press play button
Crash occurs

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/222424/test.zip)

data.title: Build failures with Visual Studio 2010
data.body:
Godot versions 2.0.2, 2.0.1, and 2.0 do not build with Visual Studio 2010 on Windows 7. I followed the steps described on the [Compiling for Windows](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/compiling_for_windows.html) page.

The initial problem I saw was with the INFINITY macro used in Godot 2.0.2, [as described in this post](http://www.godotengine.org/qa/3085/godot-2-0-2-build-fails-on-win7-vs2010). The INFINITY macro was [committed on March 8](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/0635a639e92577948ce61011ee31abedb35c05f6), so I tried version 2.0.1 (from March 6) and 2.0 to see if they would build.

Godot 2.0.1 and 2.0 also suffer from build failures with Visual Studio 2010, but it's a linker error rather than the INFINITY macro: `LINK : fatal error LNK1181: cannot open input file 'dxguid.lib'`

The Compiling for Windows page currently erroneously states that VS2010 is supported.

data.title: Crash when "Updating Scene"
data.body:
**Operating system or device:** Ubuntu 14.04 LTS x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected): Edited a node in a scene and saved with ctrl+s. Switched to another scene which had instances of this scene in it. Godot editor crashed with box saying "Updating Scene" and a progress bar at exactly 50%. This happened twice - once I edited the Z depth of a Sprite node and the other time (in another scene) I changed a Node to a Control.

**Steps to reproduce:** Have a scene instanced within another scene. Edit the instanced scene file in some way. Save (ctrl+s) then click to the tab containing the scene instances.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Node anchoring
data.body:
**Issue description:**
It would we nice to have a way to specify the base anchoring of elements, in each axis. In the linked minimal project, eight sprites should be positioned on each eight directions of another one. However, it's currently impossible to position them automatically in such way that even if we change the assets, the positioning will still be correct (ie you always have to hardcode the position according to the assets dimensions).

What I have:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1037931/14581839/2deaa4c4-03f7-11e6-9951-31218652ec64.png)

What I'd like to have (of course, the assets here are very simple, in my actual project each direction has a different texture):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1037931/14581828/f1a21f74-03f6-11e6-8a6a-84f94567bbf6.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Here's what I tried:
- A TextureFrame inside a Container doesn't work, because there's no way to set one of the two related margins to `auto` like it would be possible in css. In css, if you the left margin to `auto` and the right margin to `0`, the engine will understand that the element should be anchored to the right side of its referential, and take as much size as it needs, but no more.
- Using Sprites set up with a 90Â° rotation followed by a negative scale work for the corners, but not for the North-North / East-East / South-South and West-West directions, because this technics require the sprite to tick off the "Centered" property for one of the axis to work - and unfortunately, the other axis requires this property to be ticked on to work.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[DEMO.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/222263/DEMO.zip)

data.title: Add an exposed getter method for the private property named connection in HTTPClient class.
data.body: It seems that there's no way to get the `connection` property in HTTPClient class. Maybe we can expose a method called `get_connection` that returns the current connection of the client.

data.title: AnimationPlayer Tracks Don't Work on Objects They Create
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 7 x64 using Godot 2.0.1 Stable (x64)

**Issue description**
As part of an animation track I call a function which adds a child to the object being animated. A pre-existing animation track that has the name of the object to be created cannot modify this object, even though it exists at that path by the time any functions are called by this track.

(In my game I have attacking animations spawn a weapon deterministically. I don't know which scene file the weapon will be in advance but it will always be called "Weapon" and it will always have the same path in the parent node. I want one of these attack animations to call that weapon's "shoot" function, but I can't seem to call this function from the animation player.)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create an animation for an object. Add a track which calls a function which creates a child object. Have a function track in the animation editor which has the path to that child object, even though it does not exist in the editor (it'll have a line through it). Add a function call on the child object track at some point in the animation player's timeline that is after the child object was created. It won't work.

**Link to minimal example project**
[Example.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/221973/Example.zip)

data.title: Freeze to Hard Shutdown
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux, Ubuntu MATE, this was Godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I was replaying my scene which just generated a random number and printed it out. On one of the replays it froze my system except the mouse, but no GUI would respond to clicks in the OS or in Godot. Magic SysRq key didn't work and I was forced to do a hard shutdown. I should mention that I'm using dual monitors (laptop and TV) and that I had Godot load the game window on the TV (the second screen of course). The one thing that was notable is that on the time where it froze the game window opened in the first screen (the laptop).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Perhaps replay a scene (or the attached scene) a few times in a dual monitor set up where the game window opens on the second screen.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[Music Test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/221857/Music.Test.zip)

BTW, the scene in question is "new_scene2.scn" not "new_scene.scn".

data.title: Script editor is very slow to select text
data.body:
**Operating system or device:** Windows 10 64-bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When selecting text in the script editor, regardless of the script's length, selecting will be slow and stuttering. This occurs even if the editor is set to **Update Always**, rather than **Update Changes**. This behavior is mostly noticeable when selecting several lines of text.

This was tested on a self-compiled 32-bit build, as well as a 64-bit build from [fixnum.org](http://fixnum.org/godot/).

**Steps to reproduce:**

Select several lines of text in the script editor.

data.title: Globals not cleared properly on game quit
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
OSX, Windows, Linux (any really)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Close game by clicking OS appropriate "X" button or calling the quit signal. Expected: Game closes normally
What happened: Game crashes; malloc errors appear in the console

**Steps to reproduce:**
Put preload assets (or in an array or dictionary that contains them) in a Globals variable

For some reason, the Globals destructor is not removing these objects properly. I've seen this happen with ImageTexture and Rectangle Shape 2D objects. I had to workaround this by manually removing these objects from Global on the quit notification. Then again, I'm not sure if I'm supposed to be putting those kinds of objects in a Globals variable?

data.title: Button intercepts mousewheel inputs
data.body:
Godot 2.0.1-stable Win10

Button intercepts mousewheel inputs making it difficult to use with ScrollContainers

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new scene, add a root Control node
2. Add a ScrollContainer element
3. (Example steps) Add a VBoxContainer
4. Add a Button to the VBoxContainer, set some text
5. Duplicate the button a couple of times
6. Rescale the ScrollContainer until the vertical scroll bar appears
7. Start the scene
8. Scrolling is possible only when not hovering over a button

A silly workaround that kinda works, attach this script to every button (or attach to one and duplicate again)

```
func _input_event(ev):
    get_node("../..")._input_event(ev)
```

Keep in mind that this introduces other bugs, as the buttons dont get blurred (lose focus).

data.title: Stay safe Reduz
data.body:
Okay, I know this isn't standard fare for Godot's issue tracker, but a comment from Reduz late last month indicated that he is currently in Japan (the country which just saw two powerful earthquakes hit in the past couple of days).
http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/15/asia/japan-earthquake/index.html

I sure hope he's okay (either he felt the shaking and is unharmed or he was not in the region at that time). The Godot project will always need his skill, insight, and direction.

Stay safe.

data.title: \t not worked for string in the Label
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
**\t** not worked in the method set_text() for Label object
Example:
get_node("Label").set_text('tab test**\t**wwww')

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create the Control node
2. Create the Label node in the Control
3. Create new script for Control node
4. Set script text:

```
extends Control

func _ready():
    get_node("Label").set_text('tab test\twwww')

```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
See screenshot: http://i.imgur.com/Dw6y6YE.png
